Â Why it matters: Burns' trip is part of the Biden administration's ongoing engagement with key parties in an effort to get a humanitarian pause in the fighting and prevent a regional war.

Â Update #1: CIA chief visits Israel, region to assist with Gaza war issues (Jerusalem Post) Â Update #2: CIA Director Arrives In Israel Amid Raging Conflict: Report (NDTV)

entry.title: US, China hold rare talks on nuclear arms control
entry.summary: The United States and China held talks on nuclear arms control, marking the first meeting on this issue since the Obama administration. The talks aim to ease mistrust between the two countries ahead of an expected presidential summit. The US has expressed concern over China's growing nuclear arsenal. While no breakthroughs were expected, the talks are seen as a way to manage the relationship and prevent conflict. China currently has over 500 operational nuclear warheads, with estimates suggesting they could have over 1,000 by 2030. The US has around 3,700 nuclear warheads.

entry.title: UN force deploys for operation 'Springbok' to save DR Congo civlians
entry.summary: UN peacekeepers deployed in the Democratic Republic of Congo are determined to protect civilians against rebels, despite accusations from many Congolese that the UN forces have failed in their mission. The joint operation, known as Springbok, was launched by the UN's MONUSCO mission and the Armed Forces of the Democratic Republic of Congo (FARDC) to prevent the M23 rebels from taking control of Goma. The citizens movement Lucha has called for a sit-in in Goma to demand the departure of the UN mission and its troops.

entry.title: Israel - Hamas War -- News Updates November 6, 2023
entry.summary:
BBC: Israel Gaza war: Hamas-run health ministry says Gaza death toll passes 10,000Â The Hamas-run health ministry in Gaza says more than 10,000 people have been killed in the Palestinian territory since Israel started bombing it last month.
More than 4,000 of those killed were children, the ministry said.Â The number surpasses the UN's figure of about 5,400 killed in Gaza in all of Israel's previous conflicts with Hamas since it took control of the territory in 2007. Israel began bombing Gaza after Hamas killed 1,400 people and kidnapped more than 200 others on 7 October.Â It says it is destroying Hamas infrastructure and killing its fighters so that it will no longer be able to pose a threat to Israel.
Â Read more ....
Â WNU Editor: A look at the military situation is in the video beloâ€¦

entry.title: 'Besides al-Shifa, Hamas base in 2 more hospitals'
entry.summary: The WHO said on Sunday that it had documented more than 100 attacks on the healthcare system in Gaza, as the Israeli military said Hamas fighters were using two additional hospitals in the enclave to conceal their operations. A week after Israeli officials said they had identified Gaza's largest hospital al-Shifa as being used by Hamas for underground command centres, the military's chief spokesman Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari presented images and videos of what he said was the opening to a Hamas tunnel under Sheikh Hamad Hospital, north of Gaza City.

entry.title: Gaza medics face hard choice of who lives, who dies
entry.summary: Hospitals in the Gaza Strip are on the brink of collapse, with doctors and nurses having to make difficult decisions about who receives medical treatment due to a lack of electricity and basic supplies. Patients are being denied ventilators and resuscitation, while children undergo amputations and brain surgeries without anesthesia or clean water. The conditions are the worst ever seen by veterans of wartime medicine in Gaza, with hospitals crumbling under Israeli bombardment and severe fuel shortages.

entry.title: Blinken wraps up West Asia tour in Turkiye with little success on pause
entry.summary: US secretary of state Antony Blinken wrapped up a gruelling West Asia diplomatic tour on Monday in Turkiye after only limited success in efforts to forge a regional consensus on how best to ease civilian suffering in Gaza as Israel intensifies its war against Hamas. In Ankara, Blinken met with foreign minister Hakan Fidan following a frantic weekend of travel that took him from Israel to Jordan, the occupied West Bank, Cyprus and Iraq, to build support for the Biden administration's proposal for "humanitarian pauses" to Israel's relentless military campaign in Gaza.

entry.title: Pakistan army officer, 3 soldiers die in operation near Durand Line

Security forces launched an operation in Tirah Valley after receiving reports of militants in the area. As troops closed in, a group of militants was intercepted, leading to a shootout that resulted in the deaths of the soldiers and three militants. This incident follows recent terrorist attacks on a Pakistani Air Force base and security personnel in other regions of the country.

entry.title: Israel cuts off north Gaza as Palestinian toll tops 10,000
entry.summary: Israeli forces have cut off northern Gaza from the rest of the territory and launched intense air strikes, preparing for a push into Gaza City. The death toll in Palestine has exceeded 10,000, with over 4,100 children and 2,600 women among the casualties. Israel has vowed to crush Hamas, and the war is expected to escalate as troops enter Gaza City. The Israeli military said it had successfully encircled the north and south of Gaza, and ground troops have taken over a Hamas compound.

entry.title: Iran president to attend summit in Saudi on Gaza: source
entry.summary: Iranian President Ebrahim Raisi is set to attend a summit in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, organized by the Organisation of Islamic Cooperation (OIC), to address the Israel-Hamas war. This will be Raisi's first visit to Saudi Arabia since the two countries restored diplomatic relations earlier this year. The OIC has been vocal in condemning attacks on Gaza, and the summit is scheduled to take place after an emergency meeting of Arab League leaders in Riyadh. Saudi Arabia is concerned about the potential impact of the war on its reform agenda.

entry.title: Israelâ€™s Long War Ahead Will Be Nothing Like What Itâ€™s Faced Before
entry.summary:
Armoured vehicles of the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) are seen during their ground operations at a location given as Gaza, as the conflict between Israel and the Palestinian Islamist group Hamas continues, in this handout image released on November 1, 2023. Israel Defense Forces | Reuters
Â CNBC: â€˜Itâ€™s going to be bloodyâ€™: Why Israelâ€™s long war ahead will be nothing like what itâ€™s faced before Â * Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned his country that a â€œlong and difficult warâ€ lay ahead.Â * The IDF is supplementing heavy aerial bombardment of the besieged territory with whatâ€™s been described as a ground incursion, the details of which have been kept closely guarded.Â * Prolonged urban combat will bring a slew of deadly challenges for the IDF â€“ and likely some key advantages for Hamas, military analysts say.Â Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu warned his country that a â€œlong and difficult warâ€ lay ahead.Â The Israeli Defense Forces, after launching the largest military mobilization of troops in its history, has now entered into the â€œsecond phaseâ€ of its war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.Â The IDF is supplementing heavy aerial bombardment of the besieged territory with whatâ€™s been described as a ground incursion, the details of which have been kept closely guarded. Read more ....
Â WNU Editor: The attack by Hamas on October 7th was different in many ways(the size of the attack and the high civilian casualty numbers and kidnapped Israelis). Israel's declaration of war while making it a commitment to completely wipe out Hamas was also new and unprecedented. Bottom line. Israel is facing urban and attrition warfare coupled with astronomical casualty numbers. And when completed, Gaza is going to look like what Mosul looked like after the Iraqi army was successful in wiping out ISIS.Â So yes. Israelâ€™s long war ahead will be nothing like what itâ€™s faced before

entry.title: Hamas Says Gaza Death Toll Now Tops 10,000
entry.summary:
Reuters: UN leaders say Gaza war must 'stop now' as reported death toll tops 10,000
Â At least 10,022 Palestinians have been killed including 4,104 children in Israeli strikes on Gaza since Oct. 7, the health ministry in Hamas-controlled Gaza said.Â GAZA (Reuters) - U.N. agency leaders saying "enough is enough" demanded a humanitarian ceasefire on Monday nearly a month into Gaza's war, as health authorities in the enclave said the death toll from Israeli strikes now exceeded 10,000.Â Israel has rebuffed mounting international pressure for a ceasefire, saying hostages taken by Hamas militants during their rampage in southern Israel on Oct. 7 should be released first.Â "An entire population is besieged and under attack, denied access to the essentials for survival, bombed in their homes, shelters, hospitals and places of worship. This is unacceptable," the U.N. chiefs said in a joint statement.
Â Read more ....
Â WNU Editor: This conflict has become the most dangerous for UN staff in its history .... UN says 88 staff members killed in Gaza, highest ever in single conflict (First Post).Â Hamas Says Gaza Death Toll Now Tops 10,000Â Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll passes 10,000 in 4 weeks of war -- AP Â Hamas says Gaza death toll tops 10,000 as Israel steps up war -- France 24 Â Israeli forces sever north Gaza from rest of strip as Palestinian death toll tops 10,000 -- LA TimesÂ Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll from monthlong war passes 10,000 -- The Hill

The judge admonished Trump to keep his answers short and requested his lawyer to control him. Trump complained about the trial brought by Democrats and denied allegations of fraudulent financial statements. He also criticized the case as "election interference" and compared it to situations in "third world countries." Trump's testimony follows that of his sons, Donald Jr. and Eric, who blamed accountants for any inaccuracies in the company's financial statements.

entry.title: Europe to issue launcher 'challenge' in Seville space talks
entry.summary: Europe's top space official has announced that Europe is ready to challenge the private sector in developing rockets and supporting space entrepreneurs. This move is aimed at catching up with the growth of Elon Musk's SpaceX. The announcement was made at a ministerial meeting in Seville, Spain, where efforts were being made to strengthen Europe's struggling launcher programs and boost space exploration. The European Space Agency hopes that this challenge will stimulate new commercial space transportation services and create a new market for European space entrepreneurs.

While Ukraine insists it maintains tight control over these weapons, concerns have been raised about the potential for corruption and the illegal arms trade.

The Israeli army reported about 30 projectiles fired at northern Israel from Lebanon and retaliated. The death toll in Gaza has surpassed 10,000 since the start of the war triggered by Hamas' attack on Israel. Tensions have been high between Israel and Lebanon since the attack, with regular exchanges of attacks between Hezbollah and Israel.

entry.title: Jailed Iranian Nobel laureate Mohammadi goes on hunger strike
entry.summary: Nobel Peace Prize winner Narges Mohammadi has begun a hunger strike in an Iranian jail in protest against the lack of access to medical care. The women's rights advocate, who won the award earlier this month, has reportedly been denied treatment for heart and lung conditions as she refused to wear a headscarf during a hospital visit. Mohammadi is currently serving multiple sentences totalling 12 years imprisonment on charges including spreading propaganda against the Islamic Republic.

entry.title: Israeli forces cut off north Gaza as Palestinian death toll from monthlong war passes 10,000
entry.summary: Israeli forces have intensified their airstrikes on northern Gaza, cutting it off from the rest of the territory. This is seen as a prelude to a push into Gaza city, which is expected to result in even more casualties. The Palestinian death toll has already surpassed 10,000, with the majority being civilians. The situation in Gaza is dire, with food, medicine, fuel, and water running low, and the UN-run shelters are overcrowded. The international community has called for a ceasefire, but Israel has rejected these calls.

He will also be visiting the United States as Beijing's main representative for China-US economic and trade affairs. However, he is not responsible for technology or manufacturing, which are handled by other Vice-Premiers.

DNYUZ/New York Times: Netanyahu suspends a minister who said that dropping a nuclear bomb on Gaza was an option.Â Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel took the highly unusual step on Sunday of suspending a far-right minister from his government, after the minister said that dropping a nuclear bomb on Gaza and killing everyone there was â€œone wayâ€ of dealing with the threat from Hamas.Â Mr. Netanyahuâ€™s swift action came amid an immediate and broad outcry over the comments made on Sunday morning by Amichay Eliyahu, the minister of heritage from the ultranationalist Jewish Power party.Â In his remarks, made to a Hebrew radio station, Mr. Eliyahu also said that there was no such thing as noncombatants in Gaza.Â Â Read more ....

Turkey's President Tayyip Erdogan submitted the bill ratifying Sweden's membership to parliament, a move that has been delayed for months. Blinken stated that there was a shared commitment between Ankara and Washington to ensure Sweden's inclusion in the alliance. Sweden and Finland applied to join Nato last year for security reasons following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

entry.title: Former CNN correspondent Arwa Damon on helping children in Gaza
entry.summary: Around half the population in Gaza are under 18. That's around 1.1 million children packed into one of the most densely populated territories in the world.Â The UN says the majority are displaced, staying with their families in overcrowded shelters or camped in hospital grounds. The Hamas-run health authority says at least 4,104 children have been killed in Israeli strikes since the start of the war. In this edition of Perspective, we focus on the work of a charity set up to help children impacted by war. It's called INARA (International network for aid, relief and assistance) and was foundedÂ by former CNN correspondent Arwa Damon. She spoke to FRANCE 24's Gavin Lee.

The Aviationist: In A First, Israeli F-35I Adir Shoots Down Cruise MissileÂ The kill, scored against a missile likely launched from Yemen, is the first interception of this kind by the 5th gen fighter.Â The Israeli Air Force disclosed today that one of its F-35I Adir fighters recently shot down a cruise missile which was about to enter Israeli airspace from the southwest.Â The cruise missile, possibly launched from Yemen, was detected and tracked by the air defense as F-35Is were scrambled to intercept it, scoring the first cruise missile kill by the 5th generation fighter.

entry.title: Israelâ€™s Arrow Air Defense System Intercepts Ballistic Missile Near The Red Sea. This Is The First Instance Of Space Warfare
entry.summary:
The Arrow missile-defence system took out a ballistic missile fired over 1,000km away in Yemen Â© Provided by The Telegraph
NBC News: Israel shot down a ballistic missile fired from Yemen, U.S. officials sayÂ
Israel says that it took down the missile with its Arrow system and that Israeli fighter jets intercepted drones launched from the same direction.Â Militants believed to be Houthi rebels fired a medium-range ballistic missile from Yemen toward Israel on Tuesday, according to two U.S. officials. In a statement, the Israel Defense Forces said the missile was intercepted by Israelâ€™s Arrow air defense system, which was jointly developed by Israel and the U.S. The IDF confirmed that a surface-to-surface missile had been fired toward Israeli territory from the direction of the Red Sea, but not did specify whether it had originated in Yemen. The U.S. officials said the missile, which had a range of 2,000 kilometers (about 1,240 miles) or more, did not threaten U.S. Navy ships in the Red Sea or U.S. troops or personnel in the area.
Â Read more ....

entry.title: U.S. Says An Ohio-Class Submarine Has Arrived In The Mediterranean
entry.summary:
The USS Florida sails during "Giant Shadow," a Naval Sea Systems Command/Naval Submarine Forces exercise to test the capabilities of the Navy's future guided missile submarines off the coast of the Bahamas. David Nagle/U.S. NavyÂ Â Business Insider: An Ohio-class submarine, possibly equipped with ballistic missiles, has arrived in the MediterraneanÂ * CENTCOM on Sunday confirmed an Ohio-class submarine has traveled to the Mediterranean Sea.Â * Ohio-class submarines can be equipped with advanced ballistic or Tomahawk missiles.Â * The sub was pictured appearing to sail through the Suez Canal in Egypt, which connects the Mediterranean and Red Seas.Â An Ohio-class submarine, a type of vessel which can be equipped with advanced ballistic or Tomahawk cruise missiles, has arrived in the Mediterranean as the US continues to bolster its defensive posture amid the Israel-Hamas war.Â CENTCOM, the Department of Defense combatant command with authority over US forces in the Middle East and West and Central Asia, posted a photo on Sunday of the submarine on X, formerly Twitter, confirming it had arrived in the region.Â The disclosure of the submarine's location is significant as the whereabouts of the vessels are typically kept secret for security regions.
Â Read more ....Â U.S. Says An Ohio-Class Submarine Has Arrived In The Mediterranean
Â In rare announcement, US says guided missile sub has arrived in Middle East, a message of deterrence to adversaries -- CNN Â US nuclear submarine has arrived at the Middle East - The Pentagon -- Jerusalem Post Â Rare announcement reveals Ohio-class submarine's deployment to US Central Command -- Stars and Stripes

entry.title: US Announces 50th Weapons Package For Ukraine
entry.summary:
FILE PHOTO: Pallets of munitions bound for Ukraine are seen inside a commercial aircraft at Dover Air Force Base, Delaware, January 13, 2023. (Credit: US Air Force / Airman 1st Class Amanda Jett)
Â Reuters: US plans $425 million Ukraine weapons aid announcementÂ The Biden administration plans to announce a $425 million military aid package for Ukraine on Friday including counter drone rockets and munitions, two U.S. officials said on Thursday.Â The package is not expected to include additional ATACMS missiles. Senior congressional Republicans have urged President Joe Biden to send longer-range missiles to Ukraine, despite pushback from some conservative lawmakers against more aid.Â The planned aid package for Ukraine includes about $300 million worth of laser-guided munitions to shoot down Russian drones, according to a document seen by Reuters and one of the officials. The funds for those munitions come from the Ukraine Security Assistance Initiative (USAI) program, which allows the Biden administration to buy weapons from industry rather than pull from U.S. weapons stocks.
Â Read more ....

entry.title: Royal Mint is giving coins to 75 people turning 75, to mark the Kingâ€™s birthday
entry.summary: A new commemorative coin celebrating the Kingâ€™s 75th birthday and paying tribute to his passion for the natural world has been unveiled by the Royal Mint. To mark the occasion, the Mint is looking for 75 people turning 75 years old this year, to give them a special Â£5 coin, in honour of the Kingâ€™s birthday. To honour the Kingâ€™s lifelong commitment to sustainability, a special birthday coin has also been made from a blend of silver recovered from industrial and medical x-ray films. Those celebrating their 75th birthday in 2023 can submit their name and contact details via the Royal Mint to be in with a chance of receiving an uncirculated Â£5 commemorative coin. The winners will be drawn at random and asked to provide photographic evidence of age. They will be contacted via email from early December 2023.

entry.title: Newspoll: Peter Dutton overtakes Anthony Albanese on the primary vote
entry.summary:
Opposition Leader Peter Dutton has gained a considerable amount of ground over Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, according to the latest Newspoll.
In the first major poll since the Voice referendum was defeated, the Coalition now leads Labor on the primary vote.
The poll reports the primary vote for the Coalition is at 37 per cent whilst Labor trails behind now at 35 per cent.
On two-party preferred voting the Coalition has also tightened the gap at 48 per cent, coming in close to Laborâ€™s 52 per cent.
This latest data has marked the closest contest since the election.

entry.title: Israel launches deadliest attack yet to destroy Hamas
entry.summary:
Massive explosions are hitting Gaza City and its surroundings as Israel continues on with its deadliest campaign to destroy Hamas following the terrorist group's unprovoked attack on October 7.
The IDF on Sunday said its troops were â€œencircling Gaza cityâ€ and conducting â€œwidespread strikesâ€.
Health officials in the Palestinian territory claimed 53 people died in two blasts at refugee camps.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reaffirmed his rejection for a ceasefire on Sunday until the some 240 hostages taken by Hamas on October 7 are released.
"There will be no ceasefire without the return of the hostages. This should be completely removed from the lexicon," Mr Netanyahu said.
"We say this to our friends and to our enemies. We will simply continue until we defeat them. We have no alternative."

Â Wall Street Journal: Escalating Militia Attacks on U.S. Troops Risk Washington-Tehran ConfrontationÂ When a drone laden with explosives was found late last month lodged in the upper floors of U.S. barracks in Iraq, Pentagon officials quickly realized how close the suspected militia-launched weapon came to killing American personnel.Â In this case, the explosives failed to detonate, and there were no reports of injuries. But as the number of these attacks escalates, so too does the risk of a deadly incident that will demand a response from the U.S. military, edging it closer to direct confrontation with Iranian-backed groups it suspects are responsible.Â â€œThey are aiming to kill,â€ a U.S. defense official said. â€œWe have just been lucky.â€

entry.title: Pro-Palestinian Protesters Try To Storm Air Base Housing U.S. Troops In Turkey
entry.summary:
Using gas bombs and water cannons, Turkish security forces disperse thousands demonstrating outside the US military base of Ä°ncirlik in Adana province in protest of the Israeli genocide campaign in Gaza. pic.twitter.com/nvH6mWxljM â€” Quds News Network (@QudsNen) November 5, 2023
Reuters: Pro-Palestinian crowds try to storm air base housing U.S. troops in TurkeyÂ ADANA, Turkey (Reuters) - Turkish police used tear gas and water cannon as hundreds of people at a pro-Palestinian rally on Sunday tried to storm an air base that houses U.S. troops, hours before U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken was due in Ankara for talks on Gaza.Â Turkey, which has stepped up its criticism of Israel as the humanitarian crisis in Gaza has worsened, supports a two-state solution while hosting members of the Palestinian militant group Hamas. Since the Israel-Hamas war started, protests have erupted across the country.Â Earlier this week, the IHH Humanitarian Relief Foundation, an Islamist Turkish aid agency, organised a convoy to travel to the Incirlik air base in the Adana province in southern Turkey to protest Israeli attacks on Gaza and U.S. support for Israel.
Â Read more ....Â Update: Turkish police tear gas pro-Palestinian protesters at air base (France 24)

Trump in five of the six most important battleground states one year before the 2024 election, suffering from enormous doubts about his age and deep dissatisfaction over his handling of the economy and a host of other issues, new polls by The New York Times and Siena College have found.Â The results show Mr. Biden losing to Mr. Trump, his likeliest Republican rival, by margins of three to 10 percentage points among registered voters in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania. entry.title: Why Are So Many U.S. Artillery Gun Crews Who Were Deployed To Bombard The Islamic State Facing Health And Psychological Issues?
entry.summary:
U.S. soldiers assigned to 1st Stryker Brigade Combat Team, 4th Infantry Division, fire their M777 A2 Howitzer in Syria on Sept. 30, 2021. (Cpl. Isaiah Scott/Army)Â DNYUZ/New York Times: A Secret War, Strange New Wounds, and Silence From the PentagonÂ When Javier Ortiz came home from a secret mission in Syria, the ghost of a dead girl appeared to him in his kitchen. She was pale and covered in chalky dust, as if hit by an explosion, and her eyes stared at him with a glare as dark and heavy as oil.Â The 21-year-old Marine was part of an artillery gun crew that fought against the Islamic State, and he knew that his unitâ€™s huge cannons had killed hundreds of enemy fighters. The ghost, he was sure, was their revenge.Â A shiver went through him. He backed into another room in his apartment near Camp Pendleton in California and flicked on the lights, certain that he was imagining things. She was still there.
Â Read more ....Â Â WNU Editor: This story hits close to home. My father commanded artillery units for the Soviet Army during the Second World War. Aside from suffering hearing loss, he was haunted by nightmares from that war for the rest of his life. My father's best friend (and my Godfather) also served in such a unit, and he committed suicide 20 years after the war. Everyone blamed his war experience for his suicide.

entry.title: Ohio vote tests abortion question one year ahead of 2024 race
entry.summary: Ohio voters will decide on Tuesday whether to add explicit protections for abortion rights to the state's constitution. The referendum will determine whether the constitution guarantees the freedom to make reproductive decisions, including abortion. The US Supreme Court revoked the national right to abortion last year, leaving it up to individual states to decide. Ohio currently has a law that would ban abortions after a heartbeat is detected, but it is temporarily suspended due to legal challenges.

entry.title: In rift with military, Zelensky slams top gen for 'war at stalemate' remark
entry.summary: The office of President Volodymyr Zelensky on Saturday chastised Ukraine's top military commander for publicly declaring the war at a stalemate, suggesting the comments would help the Russian invasion. It was a striking public rebuke that signaled an emerging rift between the military and civilian leadership at a challenging time for Ukraine. The public censure of Zaluzhny came a day after the president's office replaced one of his deputies, the head of special operations forces, who after his firing said he had been blindsided by the dismissal.

entry.title: Hostage crisis at German airport ends after 18 hrs
entry.summary: A hostage situation at Hamburg airport in Germany came to an end after 18 hours. The man, who had driven his vehicle through the gates with his 4-year-old daughter inside, was arrested and the girl is unharmed. The airport had been closed since Saturday night when the armed man broke through a gate and fired shots. The man's wife had previously reported a child abduction, and it is believed to be a custody battle. No one was injured during the standoff.

entry.title: Trump leads in 5 of 6 key battleground US states as voters blast Biden: Polls
entry.summary: President Biden is trailing behind Donald Trump in five out of six battleground states, according to polls by the New York Times and Siena College. Voters have doubts about Biden's age and are dissatisfied with his handling of the economy and other issues. Biden is only ahead in Wisconsin, while Trump leads in Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada, and Pennsylvania. The polls also show that voters across income levels feel Biden's policies have hurt them personally, while they credit Trump's policies for helping them.

entry.title: How Is The Russian Economy Doing?
entry.summary:
BNN: Russiaâ€™s Economy to Grow by 2.8% in 2023, Predicts Finance MinisterÂ Anticipating a more robust financial year ahead, Russiaâ€™s Finance Minister Anton Siluanov has forecasted a 2.8 percent expansion in Russiaâ€™s GDP in 2023, a significant bounce-back from a 2 percent contraction experienced in the previous year. Siluanov attributes this hopeful outlook to full compensation for last yearâ€™s decrease and the stabilization of the ruble exchange rate.Â Rebound from Economic ContractionÂ The predicted growth in Russiaâ€™s economy marks a recovery from the challenging economic climate of 2022 when the nation grappled with a 2 percent economic decline. Siluanov, however, projects a promising 2.8 to 3 percent expansion in the upcoming year, viewing it as a reparation for the previous yearâ€™s downturn.
Â Read more ....
Â Update #1: Russia's economic situation develops steadily â€“ Putin (TASS) Â Update #2: Russia brings back capital controls to shore up the ruble (CNN)
Â WNU Editor: The Western media likes to focus on the rise and fall and rise of the Russian ruble, but the Russian economy is more than just that. So here is my recap. The civilian economy is booming and it is causing problems (inflation, labor shortages, etc.). And as for that part of the economy that is dedicated to military production .... I cannot even express in words on how huge of an impact that is having on the economy as a whole.Â But the big story on the Russia economy that many in the West have not caught up on is the Kremlin's priority to re-industrialize the country. I know the money is there to make it happen,Â but the big problem that I see will be having the workers to make this all happen.Â Update #3: The Duran's analysis on the Russian economy (see below) concurs with what I know is happening in Russia.

entry.title: Blinken says Palestinian voices key to Gaza future
entry.summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has stated that the Palestinian Authority should have a central role in the future of Gaza. Blinken made the comments during his visit to the region amid escalating tensions over Israel's war with Hamas. He met with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas in Ramallah and then traveled to Iraq. Blinken also discussed the need for humanitarian pauses in the fighting and addressed the threats from Iranian-aligned militias. He is seeking discussions on how Gaza could be governed after the destruction of Hamas.

entry.title: The Growing Sentiment In Ukraine Is That They Are Losing The War
entry.summary:
This photograph taken on November 3, 2023, shows the Motherland Monument, a 62-meter Soviet-era statue, through the trees in Kyiv. (Sergei SUPINSKY)
Â AFP: 'We're losing': Ukrainians reel from war chief's stalemate warningÂ In eastern Ukraine, where another gruelling winter is descending -- along with it a likely freeze in major frontline movements -- one Ukrainian soldier had a grim assessment of the conflict.Â The 35-year-old fighting near the war-battered town of Bakhmut went further than comments from Ukraine's most senior military official, who conceded this week that the war with Russia had reached a stalemate.Â "I've been saying that for some time now already. Step by step we're losing the war," the serviceman, who uses the call sign "Mudryi" (Wise), told AFP.Â "The longer this static war continues, the worse it is for us," he said in a phone interview.
Â Read more .... WNU Editor: The above AFP news report is a sober read and confirms what I have been hearing. The failure of the counter-offensive to break the Russian lines coupled with tens of thousands of casualties has stunned everyone I know in Ukraine. They expected at least some advances. They certainly never expected a stalemate nor Russian advances in the northeastern part of the country.

entry.title: Israel uncovers Hamas rocket launchers next to children's pool, playground
entry.summary: The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) have shared video evidence of Hamas rocket launchers being placed near a children's swimming pool and a playground in the northern Gaza Strip. The IDF has accused Hamas of committing war crimes by deliberately placing rocket launchers near civilian sites. The videos and pictures provided by the IDF show rocket launchers positioned within a residential neighborhood and a children's playground. The IDF has condemned Hamas for using the civilian population as a human shield for terror purposes.

entry.title: Israel forces kill four Palestinians in West Bank
entry.summary: Four Palestinians were killed during Israeli military raids in the occupied West Bank, according to the Palestinian health ministry and Israeli army. The violence occurred amidst the Israel-Hamas war. Two men were killed in an attack by Israeli forces in Abu Dis, while a third Palestinian, allegedly affiliated with the Islamic State group, was shot dead in a fire exchange. Another Palestinian was killed in Nuba during clashes with Israeli soldiers. Since the start of the war, over 150 Palestinians have been killed in the West Bank, and over 1,000 have been arrested.

entry.summary:
Â© Photo : Ukrainian President's Office
Â Kyiv Post: Zelenskyâ€™s Office Issues Warning After Zaluzhnyâ€™s â€˜Stalemateâ€™ InterviewÂ President Zelensky's deputy chief-of-staff suggested that military officials should perhaps keep quiet about the situation on the front lines, lest they give the Russians an advantage. Ihor Zhovkva, Deputy Head of the President's Office, has advised military officials against publicly disclosing sensitive information about the situation at the front lines.Â Zhovkva's comments came in response to an interview with Valery Zaluzhny, the Commander-in-chief of the Armed Forces of Ukraine, for The Economist. The interview also contained a link to a lengthy essay by Zaluzhny replete with military assessments.Â The deputy chief-of-staff suggested that by making comments "we make it easier for the aggressor to work."
Â Read more ....

In a statement in the early hours of Sunday, the ministry said that the submarine â€˜Emperor Alexander IIIâ€™ had â€œsuccessfully launched the Bulava sea-based intercontinental ballistic missile from the White Sea to the Kura test range on the Kamchatka Peninsula.â€ It added that the missile was fired underwater and that its warheads reached the target on time.

entry.title: U.S. Army In A Rush To Train Recruiters
entry.summary:
U.S. Army Lt. Col. Richard A. Montcalm gives the Oath of Enlistment, April 18, 2023, at the Douthit Gunnery Complex on Fort Riley, Kansas. (U.S. Army photo by Sgt. Jared Simmons)
Â Military.com: The Army Suddenly, and Chaotically, Told Hundreds of Soldiers They Have to Be Recruiters ImmediatelyÂ Â Without warning, hundreds of noncommissioned officers were ordered via email to report to the recruiting school at Fort Knox, Kentucky, in less than a week, with hundreds more set to start at the school in December -- a sudden unexpected move by the Army as the service scrambles to boost its recruiting force by 800 by the end of the year.Â The orders came after a breakdown in how the Army tracks how many recruiters it has coming through the pipeline along with retention of existing ones, according to Lt. Gen. Douglas Stitt, the Army's top personnel officer.Â The sudden depletion of recruiters caught Army planners flat-footed, with officials unable to provide a clear explanation as to what went wrong. Now, NCOs will likely have to move during the holiday season and in the middle of the school year, sowing chaos for families.
Â Read more ....
Â WNU Editor: Why the rush to have recruiters? Why the rush for new soldiers? If this does not work-out, is a U.S. draft next? You tell me.

entry.title: Stories behind Day of the Dead
entry.summary: Every November, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: DÃ­a de los Muertos, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth.

entry.title: Mexico's Day of the Dead celebrations
entry.summary: Every November 1st and 2nd, Mexico holds its largest public celebration: DÃ­a de los Muertos, or Day of the Dead, a fusion of Roman Catholic and Indigenous rituals that honor and remember deceased loved ones. Far from a mournful affair, the holiday is a time of celebration and warmth. Correspondent Enrique Acevedo talks with Mexico City's minister of culture Claudia Curiel De Icaza about the city's celebrations; with acclaimed chef Elena Reygadas about baking traditional pan de muerto; and with author Regina Marchi, who has documented the holiday's growing popularity on both sides of the border in her book, "Day of the Dead in the U.S.A."

entry.title: Has Ukraine Received Shipments Of F-16s?
entry.summary:
FILE - Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte walk past an F-16 fighter jet in Eindhoven, Netherlands, Aug. 20, 2023.
Â Bulgarian Military: Trucks brought two dismantled F-16s to Ukraine from Poland â€“ RybarÂ Rybar, a Russian think tank, asserts that two disassembled F-16s were transported into Ukraine from Poland on the night of November 3.Â The organization further reports that since the beginning of November, there has been an influx of no less than five dismantled F-16s into Ukrainian territories, inclusive of the two aforementioned jets delivered on November 3rd.Â In a recent delivery update shared on his X account [which was once Twitter], Rybar informs his followers that â€œthe eagerly anticipated shipment is now in possession,â€ referencing the arrival of two F-16 jets delivered via truck transportation.
Â Read more ....
Â WNU Editor: There are reasons to believe that Ukraine is already receiving these jets. For one, the Dutch Prime Mminister said last week that F-16s are going to be delivered to Romania for shipment to Ukraine within two weeks .... Dutch Prime Minister: F-16s for Ukraine to Arrive in Romania Within Two Weeks (VOA/Reuters), and Ukrainian pilots are already being trained to use these jets .... Ukrainian pilots begin F-16 training in Arizona (Air Force Times).

entry.title: U.S. Developing A New Nuclear Gravity Bomb
entry.summary:
The Pentagon has announced plans for a new nuclear bomb 24 times as powerful as the one dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. It comes days after it emerged China plans to double its arsenal of nuclear warheads to over 1,000 by 2030
Â Daily Mail: Maps show devastating impact of America's new super-nuke on Russian capital: B61-13 'gravity bomb' has 24 times more power than the one dropped on HiroshimaÂ * The Biden administration is developing a new nuclear bomb - the B61-13 has the potential to cause significant devastation in MoscowÂ * Simulation of bomb's estimated maximum yield of 360 kilotons of TNT could see many deaths with more than 300,000 killed and hundreds of thousands injuredÂ * Development of the weapon is primarily intended as a deterrent and to provide assurance to alliesÂ Maps have been released depicting the destruction that could be unleashed should a new type of nuclear bomb being developed by the Biden Administration be dropped on Moscow.Â The Pentagon announced this week that it is developing a new nuclear 'gravity bomb' that is 24 times more powerful than the nuke detonated in Hiroshima.Â The B61-13 is the 13th variant of the B61 family of 'gravity bombs,' which fall to their target rather than being guided.Â Read more ....Â U.S. Is Developing A New Nuclear Gravity Bomb

entry.title: ðŸ”´ Live: Israel steps up offensive with 'significant' strikes, cuts Gaza Strip in two
entry.summary: The Israeli army said Sunday its land assault on the Gaza Strip had split the Palestinian territory in two, with "significant" strikes continuing in its war against Hamas. Israeli airstrikes hit two refugee camps in the central Gaza Strip on Sunday, killing at least 45 people, the health ministry in Hamas-run Gaza said. The strikes came as US Secretary of State Antony Blinken continued his Middle-eastern tour with an unannounced visit to Iraq, as Washington tries to prevent a regional spillover. Tensions increased with neighbouring Lebanon as an Israeli strike in the south of the country killed three children and their grandmother, Lebanese authorities said. Follow our live blog for the latest updates.Â All times are Paris time (GMT+1).

entry.title: Ukraine President Zelensky Says The Israeal - Hamas War Is 'Taking Away Focus' From Ukraine
entry.summary:
Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky (R) greets European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (L) in Kyiv on November 4, 2023. European Commission President arrived in Kyiv to discuss Ukraine's accession to the EU with Ukrainian President. Â© Ukrainian Presidential Press Service, Handout via AFPÂ France 24: Gaza conflict 'taking away focus' from Ukraine, Zelensky says
Â President Volodymyr Zelensky denied on Saturday that Ukraine's war with Russia had reached a "stalemate", pushing back at suggestions Western leaders were lobbying for peace talks.Â The sprawling frontline between the two warring sides has barely moved in almost a year, with one senior Ukrainian official warning this week that the conflict was deadlocked.Â "Time has passed, people are tired... But this is not a stalemate," Zelensky told a press conference in Kyiv with EU Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen.Â The Ukrainian leader also rejected the idea Western countries were putting pressure on Kyiv to enter negotiations with Russia, amid reports US and EU officials had discussed what such talks would entail.
Â Read more ....
Â Update #1: Ukraine war: Zelensky says Israel-Gaza conflict taking focus away from fighting (BBC). Â Update #2: Zelensky Complains War In Gaza Is "Taking Away The Focus" From Ukraine (Zero Hedge)
Â WNU Editor: Zelensky is right.

entry.title: Pentagon Says There Are No Limits On How Israel Uses U.S. Weapons
entry.summary:
Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh Conducts Press Briefing. Photo by Petty Officer 2nd Class Alexander KubitzaÂ Business Insider: Pentagon says there are no limits on how Israel uses US weapons as death toll climbs amid airstrikes in GazaÂ * The Pentagon says there are no limits on how Israel uses US-provided weapons in their attacks in Gaza.Â * A spokesperson said it's up to the IDF how it uses the weapons.Â * Israeli airstrikes have devastated the Gaza Strip, and a new ground offensive could do further damage.Â The US is not putting any limits on how Israel uses US-provided weapons in its bloody war against Hamas that has killed thousands of Palestinian civilians and destroyed parts of the Gaza Strip, the Pentagon says as the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) ramps up its retaliatory attacks in the area.Â On Monday, Deputy Pentagon Press Secretary Sabrina Singh told that "we are not putting any limits on how Israel uses weapons that [are] provided," Voice of America National Security Correspondent Jeff Seldin reported.Â "We're not putting any constraints on that," she said.

entry.title: Hezbollah Targets Israel With 'Volcano' Rockets
entry.summary:
â€œBurkanâ€ Volcano Rockets
Â Newsweek: Hezbollah Targets Israel With 'Volcano' Rockets as Tensions SoarÂ The militant group Hezbollah launched missile strikes against Israel on Saturday using rockets dubbed "The Volcano," as tensions continue to soar along the country's northern border with Lebanon.Â The Associated Press reported Saturday that Israel had launched airstrikes along the Lebanese border, as Hezbollah carried out several strikes of its own against Israeli military sites.Â One of these Israeli sites, known in Lebanon as Jal al-Allam, was struck by two large Burkan missiles, according to the AP.Â Translated as "volcano" in Arabic, Burkan missiles have an operational range of 500-2,000 meters and are outfitted with sizeable warheads that can weigh hundreds of kilograms.

entry.title: New Report Says Democracy 'In Trouble' Across The World
entry.summary:
Politico.eu: Democracy in decline worldwide, new report says
Â OrbÃ¡n, Trump and ErdoÄŸan contribute to continuing downturn around the globe.Â The bedrock of democracy is trembling amid a surge of authoritarianism around the world, according to a report published Thursday.Â Hard-line rule by current and former leaders, including Viktor OrbÃ¡n in Hungary, Donald Trump in the U.S. and Recep Tayyip ErdoÄŸan in Turkey, has contributed to the downturn observed in the past few years, the Global State of Democracy 2023 report by the International Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (IDEA) has said.Â Read more ....

entry.title: 'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her
entry.summary:
She tried to censure and it came up short. Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC."
She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection.
Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress. "I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate." The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday. "Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram. Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table â€” aka kill â€” MTGâ€™s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans."
And CNN's Manu Raju added that the effort to take on Tlaib quickly died tweeting: "House kills resolution to censure Rashida Tlaib. 23 Republicans voted with Dems. MTG offered the resolution."

entry.title: Republicans to join Dems in breaking Tuberville's blockade on military promotions: report
entry.summary: Sen. Tommy Tuberville's (R-AL) blockade appears to be coming to an end, according to an MSNBC report. Capitol reporter Ali Vitali said that a group of Republicans were going to take to the Senate floor and force a vote with Democrats to marginalize Tuberville's protest against military promotions that has led to a reduced military readiness for the United States, according to reports. After a discussion about the absurdity of the protest, host Nicolle Wallace said that she recalled the era when Republicans had to be supportive of the military or they'd be shamed by leaders like Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-KY) and the GOP speaker. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? Taking to social media, reporter Andrew Desiderio confirmed the reporting, saying that the floor actions will take place tonight, where they will ask for unanimous consent on ending the Tuberville blockade. He said that he was told it would be led by Sen. Dan Sullivan (R-AK). The news comes after reports that McConnell threatened Sen. Josh Hawley (R-MO) over his bill to stop corporations from being able to give money to campaigns. McConnell reportedly pointed to Hawley in the caucus lunch and said he wouldn't be there if it wasn't for the money from his Senate Leadership PAC. He went on to threaten any member who supported the bill with a primary. It's the first such action heard about from McConnell since he suffered serious injuries from a series of falls and then appeared to freeze at various public press availabilities.

Eric Smith, who had been doubling as both the top No. 1 and No. 2 Marine Corps leader since July, suffered an apparent heart attack and was hospitalized on Sunday â€” leaving a three-star general to hold the prestigious post, according to a report published by Politico. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? The potential overextension of Smith and the stalling of more than 300 critical leadership roles was iced out by Tuberville's blockade installed as a protest against the Pentagon's policy to permit time off and reimbursement for abortions. Nowâ€¦

entry.title: Researchers hope tracking senior Myanmar army officers can ascertain blame for human rights abuses
entry.summary: A group of human rights researchers officially launched a website Wednesday that they hope will help get justice for victims of state violence in Myanmar, where one of the world's less-noticed but still brutal armed struggles is taking place.

entry.title: U.K. summit aims to tackle thorny issues around cutting-edge AI risks
entry.summary: Digital officials, tech company bosses and researchers are converging Wednesday at a former codebreaking spy base near London to discuss and better understand the extreme risks posed by cutting-edge artificial intelligence.

entry.title: Bangladesh launches new India-assisted rail projects and thermal power unit amid opposition protests
entry.summary: India and Bangladesh launched two new railway links and a thermal power plant unit Wednesday to strengthen connections and energy security in the region amid strong opposition protests in Bangladesh.

entry.title: Hundreds of foreign nationals cross Gaza-Egypt border - with Britons among them
entry.summary: The first British nationals have left Gaza and crossed the Rafah border into Egypt, the Foreign Office has said.

entry.title: Dozens of Afghans who were illegally in Pakistan are detained and deported in nationwide sweeps
entry.summary: Pakistani security forces on Wednesday detained and deported dozens of Afghans who were living in the country illegally, after a government-set deadline for them to leave expired, authorities said.

entry.title: China keeps up military pressure on Taiwan, sending 43 planes and 7 ships near self-governing island
entry.summary: Taiwan said Wednesday that China sent 43 military aircraft and seven ships near the self-ruled island, the latest sign that Beijing plans no let-up in its campaign of harassment, threats and intimidation.

entry.title: 'Neener-neenerism': Analyst shreds GOP's 'stupid and gross' conditions to fund Israel
entry.summary: House Republicans, lead by newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), are demanding that the cost of the aid package to Israel be "offset" by $14 billion in cuts to IRS enforcement funding guaranteed in President Joe Biden's Inflation Reduction Act â€” which is not only unrelated to the issue at hand, but experts say it would actually increase the deficit. The fact that Republicans are demanding an increase in tax evasion as their condition of supporting a key U.S. ally's military is not an accident, argued Talking Points Memo's Josh Marshall on MSNBC Tuesday, but a sign of how low the GOP has sunk. "I have to say, Josh, like, Mike Johnson rolling out, going after the IRS on a must-pass is past even a caricature, I can imagine, of a priority from the Republican House speaker," said anchor Chrâ€¦

entry.title: 'Desperate threat': Top Dems say Tuberville could be behind Marine leader's health scare
entry.summary: After Marine Corps Gen. Eric Smith suffered landed in the hospital Sunday following "an apparent heart attack," Senate Armed Services Chair Jack Reed (D-Rhode Island) alleged U.S. Senator Tommy Tuberville's (R-Alabama) military promotions hold may have contributed, Politico reports. Politico notes the Alabama senator "has maintained the blockade over the Pentagon's abortion travel policy, ensnaring more than 300 generals and admirals at the upper rungs of the armed forces." Reed told the news outlet, "One of the reasons, I think contributed to his condition was he was doing two jobs at once. I've read where he was working from 5 a.m. to 11 p.m. As a result, if he had, as is normal, an assistant, he could switch off." POLL: Should Trump be allowed to hold office again? entry.title: Ukraine's Zelensky says fight for Black Sea will go down in history
entry.summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky on Tuesday said Kiev's forces will succeed in their fighting in future, particularly in the Black Sea region, even if the situation on the front is difficult at present. When the aggression started in full swing, many people in the world expected that Ukraine would not hold out," Zelensky said in his daily address late on Tuesday. entry.title: Spain's Princess Leonor swears allegiance to divided nation on her 18th birthday
entry.summary: By David Latona MADRID (Reuters) - Princess Leonor, the heir to Spain's throne, formally stepped into the spotlight by swearing allegiance to the constitution on her 18th birthday on Tuesday, though boycotts by leftist and separatist politicians underlined divisions over the monarchy. The ceremony in parliament marked her coming of age, meaning she will now directly become queen after her father King Felipe VI, assuming he does not go on to have any male children. The princess, who went to school in Wales and started three years of military training in Spain in August, vowed to uphold the law,...

entry.title: Dominican Republic allows some Haiti flights as OAS arrives to meet about border dispute
entry.summary: After banning all air travel with neighboring Haiti in adiplomatic row over the construction of a canal on Haitian soil, authorities in the Dominican Republic have relaxed their stance. entry.summary: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti â€“ Across the street from the departure terminal at Toussaint Louverture International Airport in Haitiâ€™s gang-plagued capital, hundreds of anxious travelers spill out onto the road from an overflowing parking lot, listening for their Nicaragua-bound flight to be called. entry.title: Britain's King Charles begins Kenya visit steeped in 'painful' colonial history
entry.summary: By Duncan Miriri NAIROBI (Reuters) - Britain's King Charles begins a four-day state visit to Kenya on Tuesday, his first to a former colony, during which he plans to acknowledge "painful aspects" of a shared history that included almost seven decades of colonial rule. Accompanied by Queen Camilla, Charles arrived in the East African country overnight and will be received by Kenyan President William Ruto in the capital Nairobi on Tuesday morning. Buckingham Palace says the visit is a reflection of the two countries' close cooperation on economic development, climate change and security issues. ...

entry.title: Venezuela's top court suspends results of opposition presidential primary
entry.summary: By Mayela Armas and Vivian Sequera CARACAS (Reuters) - Venezuela's Supreme Justice Tribunal said on Monday it has suspended the results of an opposition presidential primary that took place this month, despite an electoral deal between the government and the opposition that allows each side to choose its candidate. The ruling could risk the wrath of the United States, which this month rolled back some oil and gas industry and bond trading sanctions in exchange for the electoral deal. The U.S. State Department has already said it will reinstate sanctions if the government of President Nicolas M...

entry.title: UK prepares to host global leaders' gathering on AI
entry.summary: London (AFP) - The UK government will welcome foreign political leaders, tech industry figures, academics and others this week for a two-day summit billed as the first of its kind on artificial intelligence (AI). entry.title: Zelensky holiday home on Crimea auctioned off by Russian occupiers
entry.summary: The Crimean home owned by Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky's family has been auctioned off by the occupying Russian authorities, the Russian state news agency TASS reported on Monday. The 120-square metre apartment in the luxury resort of Yalta on the south of the peninsula went for 44.3 million roubles ($480,000), almost twice the starting bid. There were only two bidders. The official previous owner was Zelensky's wife Olena, who bought it in 2013, a year before Russia seized the peninsula. At the time, Zelensky was still working as an actor. entry.title: Mitch McConnell on 'collision course' with new GOP speaker: report
entry.summary: Newly appointed House Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA) has a record of opposing military assistance to Ukraine. Since taking charge of the House, he has not outright said he will block Ukraine aid â€” but he has made clear it will not be coupled to his planned aid package to Israel, claiming the latter is more urgent of a need. But if Johnson continues to obstruct Ukraine aid, he is headed for a "collision course" with his counterpart in Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R-KY), who is committed to continuing to defend Eastern Europe against Russian aggression, reported Politico on Monday. According to Burgess Everett, McConnell's outspoken lobbying efforts to sway Republican senators to passing Ukraine relief "is a sharp deviation from his usual more reserved, consensus-building approach" aâ€¦

entry.title: Copper mine protests roil in Panama
entry.summary: The government approved a new contract with the mine late last week. Since then, protests have rippled across Panama, and people are afraid they could bring the country to a standstill.

entry.title: Zimbabwe's stone sculptors struggle to keep carving
entry.summary: International art collectors purchased many of Zimbabwe's massive stone carvings. But buyers stopped coming in 2000 after conflict over land reform policies led to violence. Some sculptors are still trying to keep their art alive.

entry.title: Heavy rains cause partial dam collapse, flooding in Norway
entry.summary: Storm Hans battered Norway with heavy rains Tuesday and Wednesday. Flooding of the Braskereidfoss power dam control room prevented the hatches from opening, causing a partial collapse and flooding downriver. The heavy rains provoked mudslides and swollen rivers which swept away some structures and flooded towns, requiring the evacuation of more than 3,000 people and isolating others.

entry.title: Who is responsible for Turkeyâ€™s bad buildings?
entry.summary:
Buildings destroyed after the earthquake on February 13, 2023, in Hatay, Turkey. | Murat Saka/dia images via Getty Images
Turkey is investigating and has arrested some contractors, but the entire political and economic system is implicated. Turkey is still in the middle of an emergency, reeling from the earthquake that killed at least 35,000 people last week. But the finger-pointing has already begun. The rush to punishment comes amid the grief, but also the mounting fury and frustration over the Turkish governmentâ€™s earthquake response. Much of that is focused on the emergency response â€” waiting for aid and rescue teams â€” but it is also extending to anger about policies before the earthquake, about how shoddy building construction may have exacerbated the devastation of the disâ€¦

entry.title: 10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
entry.summary:
Getty Images
How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy â€” and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russiaâ€™s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. â€œNearly every commerciaâ€¦

entry.title: Why earthquakes are deadlier depending on where you live
entry.summary:
Volunteers stand on rubble of a destroyed building in Kahramanmaras, Turkey, on February 7, 2023. | Adem Altan/AFP via Getty Images
What Turkey and Syriaâ€™s deadly earthquakes reveal about wealth. In the early hours of Monday, February 6, residents living in southern Turkey and northern Syria were woken by violent shaking, collapsing buildings, and sweeping blackouts. The earthquake buried residents in rubble and was followed by powerful aftershocks. By the following Monday, the death toll had passed 36,000 people. â€œIt was like the apocalypse,â€ Abdul Salam al-Mahmoud, a resident of Atareb, Syria, told Reuters. The country is no stranger to quakes, having lost 17,000 people to a 7.4-magnitude tremor in 1999. But while last weekâ€™s earthquake was a 7.8-magnitude quake, and had an uâ€¦
